Actress Lana Clarkson is shot to death in Phil Spector's home.
Spector is charged with Clarkson's murder.
Jury selection begins in Spector's murder trial.
Opening statements begin, after a judge rules that the trial can be televised.
Chauffeur Adriano Desouza testifies that right after the shooting Spector said, "I think I killed somebody."
A criminalist testifies that none of Spector's DNA was found on the gun, but that it was found on Lana Clarkson's body.
The judge declares a mistrial when the jury comes back deadlocked.
The district attorney's office announces it will retry Spector.
Jury selection in the second trial for the murder of Lana Clarkson begins.
Spector is convicted of second-degree murder.
Is sentenced to 19-years to life in prison.
Lawyers appear in appeals court asking to overturn Spector's conviction in favor of a third trial in the death of Lana Clarkson on the basis that the 2009 trial was unfair.
California 2nd District Court of Appeals rules unanimously against the defense's contentions that Spector's 2009 trial was unfair, and his conviction stands.
The United States Supreme Court declines to review Spector's murder conviction.
Spector files for divorce from Rachelle Short.
